review: This bag was definitely designed for photographers in mind.  There are plenty of little pouches and zippered compartments to carry all the extras like batteries chargers cards lens wipes etc and there is good space for taking a fair amount of lenses with you.  The section for the camera body will fit a mirrorless much better than a larger DSLR.I carry around the 14-24 24-70 and maybe a prime in the main section and put the 70-200 in the lower section as it won't really fit on the camera.  And that brings me to the one downside.  The adjustable sections which are held with velcro don't really hold.  It doesn't take long for the velcro to give way when you're putting your camera in the bag and it's just not the secure fit I'd want.  I don't need expensive lenses banging into each other.  So that's the downside.  I also notice the zipper catches sometimes and leads me to think that's going to be an issue one day.It's built well for the money it's a good bag but if you need "The best" bag this isn't it.  But for what it is this looks good it's easy to carry it carries a lot there's a good amount of space and room for the extras.

I really like this camera backpack! It has plenty of features that work well for me (a novice photographer). I use it casually when I go on hikes and want to have my camera with for a quick picture. I like that it can hold my tripod water bottles on the sides and all my lenses. I also got it so I can bring it on a flight with me as a carry on backpack. I unfortunately broke one of the clips in the car door. However I asked if they can get the clips to me separately and the company sent me a box with like 6 or 7 of them. I wish the clips were easier to replace but overall I was able to do it. Great durable product and great customer service! Oh I also like that it has a whistle in case I want to say hi to nature. And the extra fanny pack camera bag is very useful.

I needed a larger Camera Pack than most backpacks made for this purpose. They are fine for short trips but I'm often way out in the woods filming expeditions and I need more than just my camera gear with me; Trail gear like bear spray emergency medical kit including allergy meds for sudden hay fever and wasp stings emergency preparedness tools and equipment water bottle and rain cover gear for me and my camera equipment. And since the weather changes suddenly in the mountains - a light weight jacket. This pack has lots of room for all I need to take with me.It even has options for attaching a small tent and tightly rolled sleeping bag but I'm not sure I would use it for long overnight hiking camping and filming trips. If you do use it for that - let me know how it works.I like that it comes with a smaller "Fanny Pack" that I can use for short trips not too far away from camp. The fanny pack fits nicely into the lower compartment but I removed it to make room for my hiking gear night vision camera and lights. Personally fanny packs don't work for me as they bounce as I walk and restrict my movement when kneeling for the low shots.The Tarion Pro 2 is sturdy and well made. When I take it off to access another camera - it stands up on it's base without falling over like regular backpacks - love it. It also has the ability to strap two tripods - one on each side although I just take one and use the other side pocket for my water bottle. The interior dividers use velcro and work well making it completely customizable. It comes set up for a DSLR and lenses but I use camcorders mostly and was able to customize it for my needs.It is definitely heavier than a regular backpack that you would use for school but it is well padded to help protect your gear from damage and it is comfortable to wear; has strap support over stomach and chest for support.I really like this pack.Artist & Filmmaker: Marshall White

The bag itself is pretty roomy.  I was able to get my Canon EOS  and Canon GH50  in the backpack plus the gear that goes with it.  The improvement could be on the side of the back for securing an external Lens Bag.  I bought a new bag for my 600mm Sigma lens that had better options to attach to a backpack.I did get it awkwardly attached.  Overall I would recommend this bag.

It's got compartments for your compartments! Took it on a hike recently and had everything easily accessible when it was time to take photos. Good stuff!Update: took the bag as my personal item for a trip and upon arriving to the hotel the entire zipped compartment for the laptop zipped open and my laptop fell and broke.The zipper part for the laptop goes all the way down one side so the weight from the bag will naturally pull it open if not zipped perfectly. Poor design in that aspectSolution: stick a pin on the otherside where the zipper would slide down.
Nice bag but I had to return it because it wouldn't work for my needs.
Is a great bag wow perfect love every aspect  lots of room nice padding gear is secure  great balance with load  built extremely well  zippers very nice
I needed more for my cameras but I think I may have to get the next size up if I add more to my bag but I do love it the size now works with what I have.

This was a great purchase for all my camera stuff...the camera side pocket is nice for easy access and there is plenty of storage space for lenses and other stuff...and everything is adjustable to fit different sized lenses

I've been using this backpack for a few weeks now as a replacement to my camera bag. I travel and make videos for YouTube and so I need a backpack that can hold a lot of equipment without getting messy. You're going to need to take out all the velcro dividers and really make it your own but I love that you can.I carry a Panasonic G7 hooked up to a Ronin SC gimbal Osmo 4 Phone Gimbal 3 Apurture LED lights with small tripods a couple of microphones two extra lenses a DJI Mini 2 drone and a monopod for the main gimbal or anything else that needs it. Oh and a full size Manfrotto tripod. And a 14" ultrabook. And chargers cleaning supplies extra batteries and a dozen cables.All of that fits in there. If I unbalance the main gimbal and collapse it down as much as possible I can put the tripod in the side pocket and use the strap to hold it in place. If I don't need the tripod I put the gimbal in that position to avoid having to balance it every time.It's also quite comfy! So if it holds everything and is easy to customize and feels great why 4 stars?I'm worried about build quality and how long it'll last. The orange pull tabs on the zippers for example. You would THINK they're just rubber sleeves over a cord because that sure is what it looks like but nope. They seem to just be glued on to the ends of the cords. I would have rather just had a cord that loops around. I yanked a little too hard the other day and the orange part popped right off.Out of the box the main zipper was not properly installed. It's got a little hitch which means it doesn't completely close (a hole about the size of your pinky stays there) and I can't slide both pulls to the other side since neither one can clear that gap. It's not a big deal but it's a little inconvenient since the pull tab ends up stuck under the gimbal a lot.I hope it holds up because I genuinely love this backpack and I think it's a great deal. I can be fully set up in less than 5 minutes thanks to this bag and I can have my hands free at all times. I just hope they improve QC going forward and put in that little extra effort to make things last longer.
I do wish it had some additional smaller pockets but so far it‚Äôs been great. Lots of room!
Solidly built bag and I am really happy with the amount of space it has. I am able to use it for short trips as well as bringing my photography gear.

Just received mine yesterday began placing the dividers and positioning my equipment last night. Seems a bit more compact(which isn't bad for my 40R frame) then I'd expected. Great looking bag I'll take it out for a test later this afternoon!

The bag is well made and is of great quality. I do suggest to improve the main handle. It is very thin for all the capability of weight it handles. It has held up to this day and I can‚Äôt conclude without testing on the long run. What I do know is that this is the main grip to put on your backpack and it will be under stress every single time you use it. All in all very happy with the quality and build of the product.PS. I submitted 2 pics to show the difference of another brand comparing the handles. My old backpack never broke and with the quality of this one I‚Äôm hoping it never does. I‚Äôm just suggesting because this backpack is bigger with way more pockets and storage than my old one.

UPDATE Aug. 2022: The laptop zipper ripped out after 2 years' use which may have been my fault for not using enough care when closing it when the compartment was pretty full. Unable to get it repaired I was shopping for a new pack and found the Endurax Extra Large Camera Backpack here on Amazon which is nearly identical to the Tarion with a pocket switched around and different colors. They are the EXACT SAME SIZE despite Endurax measurements' being stated as larger. Looks like it came from the same factory down to the shoulder straps and plastic connectors and zipper hardware. Check that one if you're shopping these. Unfortunately it has the same crappy water bottle holders only with elastic vs. a draw string on the Tarion. No better at holding water bottles. (End update). There are many reviews here explaining how great this pack is and overall I agree. It goes in a completely different direction than a Lowe Pro pack I own and the design is very interesting. I needed a bit more space for extra clothing/food/emergency gear in addition to a camera three lenses tripod iPad + accessories and this pack pretty well fits the bill. I especially like the top hatch for quick camera access with the lower section for less-often-needed items. There may be TOO many pockets on this pack but I can live with that!Where it could be improved: The water bottle pockets are too short and limited in diameter by a non-stretchy top string enclosure. As a reference a 1-quart standard Nalgene bottle will just BARELY fit into the pocket and sticks out more than halfway as the base of the pocket is not as large as the top due to the tapered bottom part. The bottle will probably stay in there but just barely. There would have been room for the pockets to be taller along the side (and wider too) so this oversight is puzzling. If the pockets were larger diameter and "stretchy" they could optionally accommodate tripod legs as on other backpacks I've owned.Another issue: This pack has a tripod "foot" on one side which is a great feature but when in use the foot extends below the bottom of the pack meaning the pack will may no longer sit squarely upright on the ground. The ability of a pack to sit securely upright on the ground is nice and not all camera packs will do so.I do intend to use this pack going forward and will report any breakdowns or issues if I encounter them.

This camera bag is spacious and adjustable. The exterior is made with quality material the interior is very soft and will not damage the camera. It is large enough to carry 2 cameras flash (x2) 5-6 lenses and other accessories.
It‚Äôs big enough to fit all my equipment! I like the waterproof cover too!

I had been in need of a good "large" camera backpack for some time. My wife has used a Tarion M-02 Canvas Camera Backpack for some time and had encouraged me to get one. After trying to pack my gear into hers I realized it just wouldn't work for me. The one thing I had admired about her backpack was the quality of the backpack. Based on this I looked at the other Tarion camera backpacks and the PB-01 caught my eye. It looked large enough to carry multiple camera bodies and lenses along with other accessories. I also wanted a bag large enough to keep my gear all in one place even when stored at home. The item was as described and exceeded my expectations.  Not only will it go into the field with me but it meets my desire to keep all my gear together in one spot at all times. So you can get an idea of how large this backpack is I will list what I have in it.Top compartment: Nikon D500 and D7200 bodies with grips  Signma 150-500mm lens  Strike Finder - lightning trigger  Battery charger  Inside pouch:  3 - 72mm filters in case  3 - 86mm filters in caseTop Outside compartment: Cleaning suppliesOutside hardshell compartment: Pen  1.4 Teleconverter  2 Wireless shutter remotes  Spare battery (Camera)  Spare battery (trigger)  Spare batteries (flash unit)  2 - spare SD Cards  Tripod wrenchesBottom Compartment: 30mm 1.8 lens  50mm 1.8 lens  18-140mm 3.5-5.6 lens  70-200mm 2.8 lens  70-300mm 4.4-5.6 lens  Flash unit  Backpack rain cover  Two square filter mounts  Four lens adaptors for Filter mounts  Six square ND filters in case  Two spare SD CardsThere's tripod storage capability on the outside on either side large holders on each side perfect for a water bottle and two compartments on the "belt" suitable for extra batteries and SD cards.The bag is very well made and adjustable to help you find the best position for wearing when out and about.In addition it comes with a smaller camera bag with a belt and shoulder strap suitable to carry a camera or a few lenses in for a quick out and about where you don't want to carry the bigger backpack.

I cannot believe how functional well-made and large this camera backpack is. It fits my mirrorless camera with attached zoom lens 4 other lenses all my astrophotography equipment large off camera flash Anker power bank camera battery charger a spare Anker wall charger two Litra cube lights with accessories a flashlight and my GoPro. On each side I can attach my tripod and on the other I can attach my monopod. However it looks like there is enough room to store my monopod on the same side as my tripod and have the other side just to carry a water bottle. The only thing I couldn't fit into the bag was my Kase 100mm x 150mm filter bag but I can attach it to the outside of the backpack. I also like that I can carry a jacket on the outside of the backpack and that it comes with a full rain cover.Granted the backpack probably weighs a ton at the moment but it can store all my camera equipment until I go out into the field and just carry what is essential for that day in my f backpack. As for the smaller bag I am storing all my vlogging equipment such as wireless Lavalier mics and a spare LED panel light and accessories. Previously I had to have 3 separate camera bags . . . One to store my mirrorless with spare lenses and flash one for vlogging equipment and another for my star tracking equipment. This is a great bag if I go to a field photography workshop with just the lenses and equipment I need and the smaller bag I could use for a quick weekend trip away. By far this is the best camera backpack I own and I have tested out a number of backpacks over the past 20+ years being an amateur photographer.

a huge upgrade for me! I recently purchased a couple more lens for my collection and yeah... this bag does the trick. it hold all my lens including the Sigma 105mm 1.4 DN Art lens. Anyone who knows what I'm talking about knows how difficult it is to find a bag that can fit this lens and more. It even holds my Ipad 12.9 pro. Great bag and totally worth the price!

There are two camera storage compartments with a divider. I took out the divider to acomidate my 150-600mm lens and it works great and hold all my other lenses as well. Tried a few bags decided on the one and I like it alot.. go for it.
This bag holds both my cameras and essentials in one bag.  I love it!  I also love the easy access side pocket so i can get my main camera in and out easily witout opening the entire bag.
Muy buen producto buena calidad y suficiente espacio talvez un par de bolsas mas en los laterales no estarian de m√°s por lo demas muy bonito y buen producto

I found this photo backpack just what I needed and wanted. Plenty of room for most items you need to take on a photo outing.  Room for two cameras and six lenes and accessories.  A side door is available for fast access to your camera whether it be a full frame or a Point & Shoot.  It rides well depending on how much weight you have loaded.  Quality built and I think you will like it.
This backpack has allowed me to now carry all of my camera gear without shoulder strain. Highly recommend it.
Sturdy backpack well padded and easy to customize for two cameras and several lenses.

I‚Äôve damaged gear from not having a gear bag. Trust me it‚Äôs worth the buy. Has great amount of space. I have my film and photo camera with lenses and still room and pockets free! It‚Äôs sturdy and no worries about anything flying out. Feels amazing having a great gear bag

One concern I had was will this fit under the seat in a small plane which we have to use from our small city.  I did not want to have it gate checked with all my camera equipment so I took this backpack on a trip with no camera equipment as a test.  The backpack DOES fit under the seat in a small plane.  Will have to tuck it  width wise so that nothing extends beyond the back of the seat.  If tucked under length wise it does extend out a few inches but still should be okay (cannot tuck your feet under the chair).  The backpack is well made and has a lot of storage locations.  My only recommendation would be to have more pockets in the included small bag as there are only 2 slots for memory cards.Backpack:  Tarion Pro Large Back PackPlane:  CRJ900 CanadianAir Regional Jet

I've been using my bag for a couple of months and have taken it on a few trips.  No complaints at all about the quality of the bag.  It has a ton of space and the adjustable configuration makes it easy to tailor the bag to your needs.  My only complaint is in the general design.  You can use either the top or bottom compartment as your primary camera compartment but it's obvious the top is intended to hold most of your gear.  If you have your gear in the top the bag tends to be very top heavy.  The bottom has the easy access side compartment but has much less space.  My recommendation to the manufacturer is to switch them...move the divider up and enlarge the front access and storage space in the bottom compartment.

This camera bag comes with 2 dividers a strap and a belt to tie onto the waist. It can be used in 3 different ways like waist bag messenger bag or hand bag. The belt helps to keep the camera bag on the waist so that it doesn't need to be set down on the floor to get to the camera. It is adjustable and the bag opens away from me so it is facing me. It has tiny velcro pockets inside on the flap of the bag for SD cards and such. The dividers stick to the walls inside of the camera bag. This will most likely damage the walls over time. The dividers give each camera items their own slots. The camera bag is very very thick. The outside is more like water resistant material than water proof. If wet too much and for too long it starts to soak into the bag. The anti-dust is good. It can't be protected from all types and sizes of dust particles. I see lint on it sometimes. The anti scratch is definitely ANTI scratch so far. The handle on the outside is cushioned that makes holding the bag comfortable. The strap is very long and adjustable. The bottom is non slip. Not sure how long the zippers with the string attached to it will last. The camera bag is great but I would've liked there to be pockets on the outside for other items considering the thickness of the bag at least. The 2 tiny pockets on the inside didn't do much for me... But the bag overall is good for smaller camera items to be carried along with a smaller camera. Thank you.

Looks good on the outside but you will quickly discover that this is a bunch of half thought out features made to it look like you got your money's worth. In reality you end up using half of them because the other half are poorly designed and are not practical. But first the good stuff I guess.THE GOOD:The materials used on the outside of the bag seem to be of higher quality. The nylons are thick and durable and seem like they would be able to hold up over time. The inside materials? Eh. More on that laterThe back pads and shoulder pads have excellent cushion and this bag has a chest strap for connecting the two shoulder straps. This was a must-have for me as this strap takes the weight of the bag off the front of your shoulders. Not having this strap pulls your shoulders back and becomes very painful and uncomfortable when hiking.THE BAD:The zippered flap in the top compartment that's meant to store an iPad (according to the product pictures) is just an annoyance and here's why. This particular pocket has no way of securing its contents. There is no zipper to enclose the contents. There isn't even elastic. It's just open all the time. So this means when you unzip the side zippers and flip the pocket forward to access your camera gear which is an issue all on its own whatever is in there will fall out. Stupid.The tripod straps are maddening. They use the old fashioned ladder lock buckles instead of pinch buckles that are much easier to use. The ladder lock buckles force you to feed the tripod legs down through the loop where the tripod leg clamps ALWAYS get hung up on the strap. Then once it's in place you then have to grab onto the tiny plastic buckle and fight to tighten it. Then repeat this process over and over each time you use your tripod. These buckles should be banished from earth. What's maddening is they use pinch buckles on other parts of the bag anyway! Why not just use this clip for the tripod?! I don't get it.The hard shell compartment is almost useless. It's too low profile to practically store anything in it. They added it because it looks cool.The dividers are cheap and flimsy. The weight of your gear will likely cause them to bend and collapse especially my camera which his big and heavy. Secondly the velcro is weak and doesn't hold up against weight. The velcro dividers can be pulled apart quite easily. The dividers should be more rigid and the velcro needs to be stronger.Unfortunately I am going to return this. The cons outweigh the pros

I was hopeful spending a little more money would yeild a better bag for the most part I am right the outside is rugged and durable there is a good amount of storage (I managed to max it out with 3 bodies 5 lenes two being longer zoom lenes filters cards etc) the negatives are the inner fabric is less durable I have a 6in rip after my third outing (last photo) one minor issue I have is for some reason the added the battery storage to the quick access flap witch sits right against my lcd really afraid a minor bump could smash my lcd it's still a decent bag I'm not going to go spend twice the price to get a lowepro bag (I initially wanted)

I was worried about this bag initially after reading several reviews but after taking a chance on it it's great. Lots of good storage space and useful dividers. Some of the smaller pockets could be better divided but it's fine for how I use it.

A very good buy for fpv drone flyers!Heres a breakdown of what it holds-1 fatshark attitude v6 (with shark byte)-2 goggle batteries-bolt kit-speedy bee flasher-8 pairs of props- 5 antennas-RDQ tool kit-full soldering set up. Rossin solder solder iron brass sponge-10 spare arms-1 ev800d (removed lens only screen)-1 ev800d chargerAnd theres still a little bit more space for a few more things.The only reason i have this a 4/5 is because i only just received the bag today and time will tell how durable the bag is.

Super fantastic bag!! It is durable under hard daily use for a month with zero issues. Plenty of space and fantastic price. I use the bottom compartment for an a6000 body 18-55 lens 55-210 A mount 100-300  lens A to E mount lens adapter 55mm FE - G a water filter camp stove and fuel. The upper compartment holds clothes food mess/cooking kit. The outer top compartment holds cables batteries lens filter and other quick access small stuff. The lower pocket holds pens a small notebook hard drive various paperwork SD cards a sport thingy and a pocket knife. On the right side is a Manfrotto tripod and 18" machete w/ sheath on the left is a tent (if needed) both strapped down and in a mesh pouch. The laptop pocket holds a Microsoft Surface pro tablet with case. A sleeping bag (if needed) is strapped to the bottom or hung from the top. The small bag that comes with this kit is filled with a first aid kit toiletries/hygiene items. I still have room in both bags but not much. It's a great bag!!!

So this is going to be one of those I really wanted to like this reviews.  aaannnnd I really wanted to like this I just can't.  It feels way cheap the Velcro dividers have very little holding power; I can't see how they will stand the weight of quality gear internally the stitching and finish work is subpar the zippers are not great the fit leaves something to be desired; when the torso length is properly adjusted with the load lifters at a 45 degree angle the waist belt rides around your stomach.  This is definitely a BUDGET backpack but the thing is....it's only $45.00 cheaper than a same size in liter Lowepro so for what you get it's not a budget price.  If you have the gear to fill this then it's probably an expensive combination of gear I wouldn't put it in this...get something quality to put quality gear in.  I'm shocked at so many reviews touting this as a quality build because its just not.  If you have ever handled a quality backpack then you'll know that this is just not and you'll notice the minute you pick it up.  If this thing were $50.00 then I would say there's a market for it a budget backpack at a budget price.  But it's almost as expensive as a quality Lowepro Tactic 450 save another $45.00 and get something that won't fail you. If this thing were the same quality and price as the LowePro then I would probably choose it as I really like the layout of this.  Step up the quality even if it means a price increase and I would be a buyer or lower the price drastically and I would still return it because I have no use for a pack that will fail....but I think a lower price point is deserved.

I just love this bag.  It looks great...but more importantly its capacity is outstanding.  I was able to get my camera extra lenses various peripheral equipment like extra batteries charger cables filters etc.  Including my 15 inch laptp my ipad and my Ronin RS 2 Gimbal with all its assorted parts.  Took it across country on airline fit perfectly in the overhead.  Was just exactly what I was looking for.

Arrived quickly and undamaged. First off it's new and I haven't had a chance to put it through any trips or excursions so at best this write up is only on first glance of the Tarion Pro bag.  It's a big bag and about the largest you can get to carry-on an airline in fact it may be too big for some of the smaller aircraft to put in the overhead.  The amount of flexibility on first look is overwhelming lots of compartments pockets and zippered areas to become familiar.  If that's all you are looking for it gets better.  Many of the compartments are sectioned off with Velcro dividers so you can tailor them to your equipment.  So on first look it's big has many compartments and many of them are adjustable for your needs.  The quality looks good and I would expect it to last a good long while but will have to reserve statements on longevity until I've used it a bit.  I give it 5 stars on room and flexibility only actual quality TBD but looks good.

It's not the fault of the bag but it's almost too big for how I use it.  I like to carry my dslr with me everywhere on vacation and I wanted a bag with a little extra room to carry some added daily essentials.  This us just so big the that I found myself making excuses not to bring it.  As a carry on bag it will fit in the overhead but not under the seat.It is sturdy well made bag with lots of storage....just like it's says so I won't hammer the bag on my decision to get it.  Just wish I went with the smaller version.

So this bag is actually smaller than I thought. I had purchased the TARION XH prior and really liked the bag but There were no outside bags meaning i had to open up them main compartment for everything wether an sd card cable or gimbal. Now the comfortability for the XH is amazing the straps feel great on shoulders. Received this one a few days ago and was able to fit everything and a little more than the XH. I love the way you have outside pockets for small storage. BUT the shoulder straps do not feel as comfortable not enough padding on them and while with the other bag I could walk around with it without issues with this TARION PRO the quicker i can get it off the better. Im thinking of returning it for that same reason. Other than that its not a bad back. But at the end of the day and backpack that you cant stand on your back is not ideal.

Let me begin by saying this bag is more than I expected but in a great way! I'd researched videos pictures and reviews on many bags before finally settling on this one. Let's just say there's no "settling" involved. It's exactly what I needed!WHAT I HAVE INSIDE:- Canon 6D Mk II w/ battery grip- Canon 70D- Canon 10-18mm lens- Canon 17-40mm lens- Canon 18-55mm lens- Canon 55-250mm lens- Canon 50mm lens- Tamron 150-600 G2 lens- External flash- Multiple filters- Multiple SD cards- Multiple batteries- Battery charger- Rainfly- Lens cleaning kit- Remote shutter- Business cards- Pens- Full size tripod- Small tripod- 15.6" screen full size laptopPROS:- Very large spaces in each compartment- Sturdy build- Strong back hip and shoulder support- Included rain fly- Extra travel bag includedCONS:- It might be a bit large on shorter people- Even with the tellest setting (on the shoulder strap height adjuster) the hip pads are at my bellybutton. I'm 6'3" and it's a tad too short for me. Better than nothing but not quite the correct placement for hip support for someone my height.

I'm a full time working editorial photographer and this bag surprised me in every possible way. The build quality is excellent but what really stands out is the innovative design when compared to offerings from your typical brands. The size appears much smaller but it can easily hold an ungripped A7iii 70-200GM Tamron 28-75 and even squeeze in the large 16-35gm or a series of primes such as the 55 35 50 85 or 90 easily while still having room to spare for smaller devices such as Gopros a zv-1 or even a Fuji X100V. The other pockets can safely hold memory cards an Ipad pro 12"  batteries and the pocket easily holds a befree tripod securely. What's great about this backpack is while I can pack it to the brim for more involved shoots I can also easily pack down and make it an everyday carry due to the looks fit and size. Overall I highly recommend this backpack if you're looking for an everyday driver that could also convert itself into a full gear bag when needed.

Best bag ever! I‚Äôd been looking for years and nothing worked for me. I travel a lot and don‚Äôt like unpacking and packing what I can fit. This bag lets me pack everything I could ever want. When fully loaded the bag is heavy and can carry the weight well with all the reinforcement they have carefully added. Easily accessible to all pockets with the unique zipper handles. All zipper work very nice as well. One of the best things about this bag is that it stands up!!! I‚Äôm tired of constantly wrestling my bag and leaning it up against something. This bag will stand straight up while accessing equipment and changing lenses‚Ä¶etc. also I can easily fit my 14‚Äùx9.5‚Äù laptop in the laptop pocket without having to cram it in and struggle to take it out. I‚Äôd buy it again when I need to replace this one but it is holding up very well.

Well built resistant but smaller than it looks in picture. Not for videographers willing to carry Instruments like lights batteries chargers wireless microphone systems lenses drone and cables all together. Perfect to carry basic tools. If you can put in another bag extension cords drone etc it‚Äôs a good choice. If you think to use it to carry all your equipment at once this has not enough room.
Nicely made I put a small cooler on top to put a few water bottles and ice packs. Love it‚Ä¶

Almost perfect all around photo pack!I was able to fit my DSLR with jet lens attached and had 5 more slots to lenses. There is space to fit a 9.7 iPad on the top modular compartment but wouldn‚Äôt trust it for travel. It was also a bit tight and might risk a broken tablet. That same space would work perfect for an iPad mini.Those smaller compartments on the outer shell were a fair size just wish for a bit more space on those areas as well.The bottom modular compartment came packed with the shoulder bad. I took out the shoulder bag and am using it for another camera set. The space in that compartment fit a Mavic 2 Pro carrying case perfectly.My 13 inch MacBook Pro fit a littler snug wish it had a littler more slack but the Mac is an older (fatter) modelThere is a really tight compartment at the base of The bag with a small pouch the slides out. I used that space to store the rain cover.Overall I think the bag is the Swiss Army Knife of camera bags that will let you carry all you need and have a bit more space for a little more.

This is not just a "camera bag." Whenever I travel I have to carry a separate laptop bag a bag for my cpap plus other stuff (e.g. jacket medicine). Now I can carry one bag as a carryon that holds all my important items. It will also slip over the handle of my rolling suitcase. Hiking staffs will attach to the pack (tripod carriers work well for that too). I can fit my laptop iPad Kindle cpap machine (each of these in their own padded area - and reach any of them without tearing my whole pack open) medicine hiking staffs jacket/sweater pens powerbank iPhone cables with pockets for all sorts of other stuff with configurable dividers and - oh yeah - a camera. It's so well thought out. Even if using it just for regular hiking and camping it allows you to configure and segregate your gear in a myriad of ways using the padded dividers so that you can really organize yourself anyway you want. Don't need the dividers leave them home. The way this is organized you can open just the area for the equipment you need. No having to unpack everything to get what's at the bottom. It's amazing! This is the cleverest pack I've ever owned. Five stars +++.

This is a medium to large size bag!I was looking at a small to medium size bag originally.  But after weight out all the features and my need I decided to choose this bag as my final unit to purchase.Pros:1) Top load for quick camera access2) Plenty of spaces for either lens accessories flash or personal belongings on short to mid-range trips.3) If needs to the bag has space to load enough gears on field studio work.4) For #3 that means it has the space for a lap top plus a pad.  Which is a plus.5) I like the slave bag.  In case I need to part from the main bag.  I could leave the big bag in the hotel room and carry the small one for short excursion.6) 'Quality is really good.  Stitch line is firm and the shape is better formed than most of the ones out there.Cons:1) Still bigger than what I am truly hoping to purchase.  But I have not found it yet!I would suggest my friend to purchase this bag if they need one.

I got this for my series x Xbox which measures just under 6"x6"x12" (LxWxH) and it is super tight in the bag. And there's no room for much else (one controller and cables). It may say it's 16 inches tall but it's not square - at the top it narrows when it's zipped to about 4 inches. And I can't even use it as a back-up camera bag. With the padded inserts it only fits one body a med-long lens and then only a couple short primes wedged into the corners.

It fits everything and then some.  I love all the pockets it holds all my extra lenses camera body remotes flash...I like that everything is right there. The shoulder pads are padded and the shoulder harness is adjustable to get the right fit.  I have gone day hiking with it fully loaded (about 30lbs) with camera equipment water and snacks and it never hurt my shoulders or back.  It also comes with a mini shoulder bag which comes in handy when I don't need everything in the bag.  Worth every penny.

The pack looks nice but it was too small to hold my gear comfortably. It also needs a waist strap/belt to keep it from bouncing around while hiking and the chest strap is far too high - even after adjusting to its lowest point it kept riding up and hitting my neck  - not acceptable. The pack is smaller than you'd think - looks big in the picture and the dimensions make it seem like it's roomy but it isn't - the design is such that a lot of space is wasted. A lot of potential here but not realized. I had to return it.

Fits everything I needed for 1/10 TC and 2wd/4wd buggy. It has enough padding to protect your electronics without the bulk. My previous transmitter case is literally as big as this but can only fit a sole M12RS.1.) Has a huge compartment at the bottom for my power needs: x4 port 100W ac/dc charger x4 brick 2s lipo and x2 shorty packs (but can fit another pair).2.) Main too compartment fits a Sanwa M12... which means you can basically fit any other transmitter. Also squished in there is my electric air can.3.) Front hardshell compartment fits smaller electronics like programmer cards alkaline batteries etc.4.) Too soft shell has all the power cable balancer boards and charging cables for the charger.5.) Side water bottle compartment big enough to fit a canister of Simple Green foam.6.) Has a laptop compartment which I use to store manuals and a custom cut lexan pit board.

I'll start off by saying I've used a variety of camera bags and this one has been one of my favorite. I am a content producer and can be very hard on my gear when trying to get "the shot". This bag is built to handle life outside the studio. It's sturdy shell has protected my gear on long hikes tough falls and harsh weather. Also there is plenty of room in the bag to fit any piece of equipment I need. There dividers allow me to customize how I pack my bag and can be removed in case i need to take more travel gear and less camera gear. The hip straps and back support are also really nice when carrying around a heavy set up and on long hikes. I've had uncomfortable bags in the past and this one is definitely not one of them.So basically I give this bag an easy 10/10 and recommend it for anyone looking for something that goes beyond the simple photo studio. The only time I would not recommend this bag is if you have a small set up and only use lets say one lens.

I recently purchased this backpack for a trip. I do landscape photography so I needed a new pack that can carry several lenses and other accessories. I found this pack to be a little heavy(without my gear) but I could fit all my gear in it easily. It was comfortable for long hikes and seems to be durable. So far this is a great pack for hiking but a little too big for a quick day shoot. I took out the small bag that came with it to better fit my gear I don't see me using it as it is too small for my gear. My only con is that it has a squeaky noise when walking. I have not been able to figure out what the cause of this but I hope to. If I could chang anything about this pack it would be the waist straps I wish they were removable or retractable. I just don't like waist straps. All in all this is a good pack for a fair price.

I am pretty happy with this bag. With all my stuff packed it probably weighs 30 pounds. After making adjustments to the straps it stays snug to my back and is comfortable to carry.I do have a problem with how it is layed out. There are basically 2 main compartments to store your camera üì∏ stuff but no way to combine any of those dividers. There is absolutely not a chance I can get my 600mm lens into this bag.  The only other issue I see is that there are no tie downs on the top of the pack for tripods. Yes you can carry a tripod on each side of the bag but nothing on top.The bag physically looks phenomenal I will admit though so for now I will have to carry my 600 separately.

I am very satisfied with the camera backpack so far. It feels really nice and seems to be made of high quality materials. There are so many ways that you can customize the setup to hold all of your gear exactly how you want it. It's got a bit of weight to it on its own but this is because it is made of good materials and there is lots of padding to keep your camera gear safe. I especially love the small shoulder bag that comes with it. I bought this bag so that I can take all of my camera gear with me on a trip to Iceland but so I also have a small bag for just the camera when I am out and about and don't need all of my gear. I can't wait to bring it on my trip! And while the bag is plenty big to hold everything you need it should also satisfy many international airline carry-on size requirements which is great because I would not want to check my camera gear.
Just great I really like it. Enough space for the camera and all the gears.

The flaps over the zippers and straps near the openings slow down the packing and unpacking process.Too much of a good thing can me Bad.  4/5The bag offers many options for your gear. I have two systems: Canon 5DMK III and Sony a7iii with L series Sigma 85 - 1.4 and Tamron 28-75 - 2.8 glass and the compartments allow for all of it as well as my 15‚Äù MacBook Pro light meter color checker tethering cords batteries and memory cards. 5/5The removable bag is a plus for traveling light and can be configured as needed. You can use it to carry speed lights and other accessories. 5/5The shoulder straps have a three point adjustment system where you can raise or lower the height as well as the opening to fit your arms and shoulders. 5/5A small functional tripod or mono pod may add weight so be ready. 3/5Once it‚Äôs on your back it lightens the load and burden of carrying it during your outdoor experience. 4/5Overall rating 4.5kdmorriskdmorris photographyPhiladelphia

Awesome camera backpack especially if you have a lot of gear to carry. It‚Äôs comfortable pretty sturdy and has an insane amount of storage and pockets. Only downside is when packed full of gear backpack can‚Äôt stand up without falling backwards. So you‚Äôll have to set it down against a wall or something solid so it doesn‚Äôt just roll backwards. For the price tag I‚Äôd definitely recommend.

I needed a bigger bag for my photography business. The bag is very comfortable to wear and holds a TON of equipment. It feels like quality material. The zippers feel a little cheap so I use them gently. None have broken. I do wish the strap for tripod didn't have to be undone to get into the top of the bag but it's not a big deal. Still pretty fast to get in and out of.
Traveling with this was great. Comfortable and sturdy. Rain cover came in handy.

PROS: Great material lots of compartments easy working zippers lots of storage ample room for many lenses camera drone and all accessories water repellent additional rain cover for better rain protection.CONS: Velcro dividers seem a bit flimsy and velcro attachment points seem a bit weak. Shoulder and waist straps are not made for husky people. I will need to modify mine by adding straps.

I was super skeptical of buying another camera bag for my events but when i hit the bullet on this I was not disappointed. Comes with all the dividers you need even a diagram to make a basic setup.Top section : 2 D750 35 50 85 and two chargersBottom section : 1 DSLR flash 35 24-70 charger cleaning kit.Zipper pouches: spare batteries SD card pouch camera straps. All fit!!For $100 I say worth it because I like to only take 2 lenses to gigs but when I go on a trip I never know what to use! Get it guys it seriously is worth it. Weight distribution is phenomenal easy to access equipment

Where I live has some rough terrain and sometimes Ill be running around or climbing up steep terrain/rocks so being able to put all my gear in the bag lets me move around much easier. I can also carry water food and more gear than without a bag which helps a lot for longer hikes. The side pocket is also nice for quickly grabbing the camera.

While this backpack seems well built the color choice is misleading. Bordering on false advertisement. Take note that the majority of these reviews are for the ‚Äúblack‚Äù color. That ‚Äúcolor‚Äù is in fact an entirely different backpack. The other ‚Äúcolor‚Äù is much smaller. I thought that Amazon was cracking down on these bait and switch tactics but this one snuck by their radar. Like I said the backpack I received is well built and designed and is actually very nice. But it is not what I thought what I was getting.

At first I was concerned that I would not be able to pack my lenses camera and Gimbal plus all related accessories into the bag. I was wrong. Yes it is a tight fit but considering there is nothing loose or banging around I consider that a plus. The included fanny pack is perfect for my go pro and its accessories and as soon as I get my laptop i‚Äôm all set. Just wish I had a pocket for a change of clothes... but where I‚Äôll be going I won‚Äôt need clothes. ;-)  Zipper rings makes securing the pack painless and the included rain cover makes it ideal for camping and long hikes. Lots of room for lenses flash and charging cables. Fits my 15 inch laptop quite well.It's great to fit most all of my camera gear in one place and easy access to my camera from the top of the bag. Easily holds my tripod with straps on side of backpack.

This is a pretty solidly built bag. Feels very sturdy and well padded. It holds all my current gear including my mirrorless camera the two lenses I have for it currently and has room for one more I plan to get. And the few other compartments it has are fine for batteries and small stuff. I‚Äôm going to need a separate bag for my flash and associated equipment though. I was never a big fan of camera backpacks. I prefer shoulder bags but these days I carry several big lenses on many shoots and I need to have my gear with me in a way that doesn't hamper movement. This backpack beats all the competition for durability function and price point. I have to admit that I have been a fan of another company's bags for years but when I compare all the features quality of materials and the price I really believe that Tarion bags are the best of category. This pack impressed my wife so much that she is buying one for all her gear. Once you see one of these in use you'll want one too.

Absolutely love this bag and  I fit in two DSLR Cameras lenses 200-500 70-200 18-300 11-16 SD cards Batteries and Laptop sure that is only when I travel and its heavy than.The only thing I do not like is the squeaking noise that is right on top on the shoulders and therefor close to my ear and I have TN disease so it can trigger horrible pain for me. But I sure would recommend this bag its well made and I would sure buy it again and the extras that comes with it is awesome too

Bag is well made with thick material and heavy stitching has survived several trips already with no signs of wear. I'm quite concerned with the middle 'pick up' strap used to lift the bag from the floor from a standing position though compared to all my bags before it seems like this is severally under sized and expect it to be the first part to rip. Note this bag is too large to fit in the overhead compartments of region jets like a CRJ700 but it does still just barely fit under the seat.

I needed  a camera backpack with more room I have outgrown my last one. This camera backpack has a lot of room and the compartments are set up nicely. Your equipment is not jammed into it either everything slides in and out nicely. I was even able to fit a 400mm Sigma telephoto the camera body with lens attached a few more lenses and some sound equipment wow.  When needed I'll be able to fit my DJI Osmo with the camera mounted.  I loaded it up and put it on and it felt good not heavy but the real test comes when I take it into the field. I also like the look style and colors it hard to find a bag that actually looks good.  One concern is the main handle for lifting it just does not feel sturdy enough. Otherwise a great camera backpack.
Love the zipper pulls. Plenty of room and easy to configue. Very good quality.

Only complaint I have is with the straps. First wish the height of the upper strap was adjustable as i find it to be too high. Also the shoulder straps loosen over time. Had to tie a knot in them to prevent the pack from riding too low.  Wish it had loops to clip on gear such as a GPS. Other than that it is great for securely holding all my gear. Have to fear is any of it being damaged.

This bag has been amazing! I do weddings for a living so I‚Äôm constantly jumping in and out of cars at parks on streets and fields. For a photographer this will carry everything you need plus some.3 mirrorless5 primesDrone gearBatteries16inch Laptop and more.

Very nice bag. Its a decent size and carries a decent amount of equipment.I wish the bag pockets were set up opposite. I pack my lenses in the top of the bag and camera with a lens attached in the bottom. When I use my camera the weight shifts and is too top heavy.When I take off the bag to access my lens to change the bag tends to fall over due to the top heavy weight.Also the bag should have hard shells for all 3 compartments not just the battery accessory pocket in the middle.

I can fit everything I need plus diaper wipes and a couple pull ups inside this thing.  My tripod is secure on the side via snaps and buckles and everything can be adjusted to fit.  I have done many hiking trips with this since I bought it 4 months ago and it holds up and holds more than you need.

The good: There are no bags out there [far as I can tell] that allow you to carry TWO sets of camera/lenses and retain the compact size which allows you potentially stow it under an airline seat.The bad: The designers either took the month off or got lazy when they put the finishing touches.- Had a lockable zipper pair [which I absolutely love] but any benefit is negated by the fact that you can access the side pocket which has no such zipper to steal the very things you are trying to protect.What was the thinking here? Put one on the SIDE pocket!- The hardshell pocket is WAY underutilized. Seriously you dedicate a pocket for some stitched on mini pockets for SIM cards? Is this a joke?  No stretch pocket instead? A zipper pocket?Compare this to your larger version of this same bag - the hard shell pocket is much more practical. C'mon guys! Seriously!- Top zipper pouch - Again it's like you are getting a VERY stripped down version of a decently-equipped car.Remember people like to organize things better - brushes spare caps lens cleaner lens cloth.- Bottom side pocket for quick camera access. Why can't the inner flap have a pocket like its bigger versionBOTTOM LINE: Tarion you would have an EXCELLENT bag in a class by itself were you to just make some minor changes to this bag.Is this far too much to ask?

The media could not be loaded.                                                                                            ¬†I've had this bag for awhile now and have used it extensively. I am very happy with this bag. I found myself in a situation where I needed to carry my larger video editing laptop and I was having trouble finding a bag that could fit it and my camera gear. I just got back from vegas covering shot show and was able to fit everything including clothes in this one bag and it fit as a carry on.  It is durable and I like the way I can easily reconfigure when adding gear or in my case making room for clothes.  I don't think there is another bag I have seen that can match this one for my needs especially at the price. Well done.
Great amount of space and storage.

I bought this for my husband who had 2 camera cases and many other storage boxes/bags for his two cameras two big lenses unipod and loads of miscellaneous must haves. I think he was skeptical of how much it would accommodate and was really excited about it holding everything he needed. He‚Äôs not a hiker but he said it‚Äôs nice to be able transport the bag like a backpack.

I've been carrying one of those over the shoulder bags for ever and it has worked until I started carrying extra lenses and cleaning supplies.  Of course I'd have to carry my tripod separately.  This bag holds all my gear and I'm able to carry other things that I would really like to have with me for shoots. .... wipes towels lens shrouds charger portable charger.  I love it.Also I was worried that he bag would get top heavy with most of my gear in the top and collapse - it really doesn't.  It has enough structural integrity to hold itself up. I purchased this for my new Nikon Z9 only to find out it was not big enough for the Z9 with the 24-120 attached. Much smaller than I thought is was going to be. Not deep enough as well made for something like the nikon Z7 or 6

I love this bag was initially  going to return it  dealing with the ups store in brunswick maine store#3338 was a nightmare . Its super big bag and heavy but great protection  for gear. Im going to use it to pack all my gear in and use little bag to only carry what i need :)

I was anticipating a little roomier bag as it boasts that it can hold two cameras. I cannot fit my Nikon D6 In the bottom without having to force it and open both zips to get it out. It only fits on the top backwards which leaves very little room for other accessories. It‚Äôs also very uncomfortable to cart around. Needs a waste and support strap... that would make it a nice bag for hiking but I probably won‚Äôt use it for that.It‚Äôs ok and I made it work but I‚Äôll be upgrading before too long.

Picking the box up to bring it into the house raised an eyebrow... It's not super heavy but enough to right off let you know this is not an ordinary camera bag. Very impressive. It appears to be ready for the long haul and lots of use and abuse. I have a lot of equipment and sadly its not going to be big enough for much more than a couple of cameras and lenses. I haven't spent enough time on it yet but that is my first impression. I will come back to that after a trip or two.. I do and will recommend this bag...I have a lot of experience with bags and this one is first rate..

This bag is ideal for the person going on extended day hikes.  There is enough room to hold camera gear as well as personal items needed for a long hike.  There is enough room that I can even take my backpacking stove to have some coffee or hot soup.  The shoulder straps are quite comfortable and the waist strap is substantial enough to be useful. You can wear this pack comfortably for the entire day.  The camera gear storage area is well padded.  Comes with a separate bag that can be used by itself when you don't need the backpack  Also comes with a rain cover.  If you want a bag for extended day hikes you won't find one better than this.
Holy cow this thing is big. I fit ALL of my camera gear inside and then added my second camera and lenses too plus the tripod. In the event I get a smart car (not likely) it'll fit too.
It fine. certainly not a premium product but also was a fraction of the cost. If I were a pro I would not be happy with this. But it will serve me just fine.

Completely what I wanted.  It has space for my camera and gear and plenty of space for water bottles too!  It held up well to hiking in the desert and didn‚Äôt become uncomfortable like my previous backpacks would.  It packs a tripod very well and despite climbing and scrambling over and under rocks my tripod was not pulled out.Unfortunately mine didn‚Äôt come with the Velcro strap and I will leave that for my review of the seller.

I went for a camera bag that could hold (almost) all my equipment for traveling and adventure photography - and this is the one to have!It is sturdy well-built comfortable and most of all - large. I can easily fit my larger Pentax DSLR my mirrorless Sony and lenses for each in the compartments. Theres ample room for accessories and cables notebooks harddrives... you name it. It is worth the investment just to know you have all your stuff available wherever you are shooting. I personally don't use the removable shoulder bag but rather use the space for the second camera to live.Overall very happy with my purchase.

I am a full-time professional photographer and needed a bag that would hold a lot of gear be well made have good padding to protect from stuff have several pockets and dividers for organization and be comfortable to carry. This backpack covers all the bases. The only gripe I have about it is the fact that the top of the bag angles inward and when it is laying flat what I have in the top outside pocket tends to want to fall out. But that is a small gripe other than that I like the bag and it appears to be made to years of daily use. I would buy it again.

I'm (hopefully) going to be going to Europe for a month this summer and I needed a bag that could transport all my camera equipment plus my CPAP machine since I can't pack it in my regular luggage. This pack can support both my CPAP my camera equipment and my laptop all in one. Even if this is the only time I use this pack it will be worth the money.

I have a small frame and this relatively large bag has innovative and simple methods for fitting fairly comfortably.However there are a number of quality issues Multiple zipper pulls broke after 2 weeks‚Äô use small storage pockets ripped at the seams after the second use and the Velcro on the divider between the top and bottom of the bag is not very strong resulting in items from the top being compacted in the bottom of the bag.I would return the bag if I had had an opportunity to use it in the field prior to the return cutoff. What a great design. So much quality and innovation. This thing far exceeded my expectations. Large body with a grip and a lens attached 4 other lenses 2 flashes. Lots of odd and ends. And room to spare. Laptop and iPad storage.  Amazing padding in the straps and the back. This thing is very large but doesn‚Äôt feel it at all. I‚Äôve gotten other backpacks from amazon and this one blows them away. Have been a lowpro guys for years and this is my choice by a long shot.

Most of my camera equipment fits well.  Another happy customer sold me on this bag when he pictured the same camera and long lens that I have fitting in the bag.  I took it on a plane with me - tripod attached (head packed in a suitcase).  To make it easier to handle in the airport I attached it to a small wheeled dolly that could be put under the seat in front of me.  I'm very pleased with the way it protects my gear and just how much fits in the bag.  I don't/haven't hiked with it yet so I can't answer questions regarding that however I did carry  the backpack onto the plane and it is evenly balanced.  Worth what I paid.  I am pleased

I was very impressed with the quality of this backpack. I was running out of room in my old backpack and knew it was time to get one with more storage space. Well I found it. It is built well and gives you options in regards to storage within it. I would most definitely encourage anyone to take a closer look at this product. It is a good product at a great price.

I have another much more expensive pack that does not have all the features and versatility of this one. Great quality and very well thought out. Absolutely love this product so far. It is extremely comfortable and holds my camera the 4 lenses that go everywhere with me my laptop and the cleaning kit I carry for my camera and lenses. Plus there is still additional room. It is very handy how it is adjustable to height in more than one way. You can personalize it to fit you best. I am very anxious to use the around the waist pouch when I go hiking in the mountains for quick access as carrying a camera around my neck is very uncomfortable. Very pleased with my purchase!!! Have already passed the name on and showed this product off to numerous people.
This is not a bad backpack. You can actually fit a ton in there. However if you put too much gear on it it will look bulky and I felt like it was going to fall apart over time.

This is a nice camera bag.  It was actually bought to store other equipment (GPD MicroPC Netgear Cell Router and some other accessories).  It preforms this function quite well and reduced the number of separate bags into a single one.It has the ability to adjust the dividers which is great.  This way one can customize the storage arrangement to fit the items being carried.  The product seems good quality but I can't speak of longevity at this point.  I also like the different carrying options via the shoulder or hand.  This way it fits life quite well.This bag met the needs it was bought for and I would buy it again for its purpose.
Ton of spaces and compartments to carry all of your digital/camera needs. I have a DJI Mav 2 drone DSLR goPro DJI Mimmo along with lighting and tripods all in one place!!

I now use that space to carry my electronic accessories for quick removal in airport security lines etc.

What I like about this is the compartments have Velcro dividers so you can rearrange them to be however works for you. This backpack is amazing for it's price!!!!!!!The quality is just great and there is so much space for my camera equipment. I enjoy having most of my equipment in one bag.  I no longer get to my shoot and wonder if I have the correct filters lenses and extra body with me.  You get the idea. A ton of compartments

I can't give it all 5 stars as I've only had it a short time but I love the space it holds all my equipment and more plus it's comfortable to wear! Fabulous camera bag for all your lenses; cards; spare gear and the camera witch has it‚Äôs own removable on the go bag built in! The removal of the dividers allows you to customize the compartment needed. All items are well protected!

I got this bag to supplement my normal pack that has everything. This bag is big enough for my Panasonic G85 and a extra lens and a few batteries. The padding is good and I feel like it would keep the contents safe if I ever dropped it. This bag has a very sturdy well built feel to it. I think Tarion made a nice bag here.

I love how much I can fit in this bag and how well organized and protected everything feels.  My favorite part is that detachable bag that I currently use to store all my audio gear.  It's great that when I'm trying to set up audio when filming an event that I can just carry around that tiny bag that has all my solutions in it.  Sometimes that saves me quite a bit of walking!

Great bag only downside is you may need to have your larger lenses in a separate bag. It may fit a single camera with a 200mm lens but that‚Äôs all. However I usually carry a dslr (Nikon d5600) and an slr (Minolta 370). Surprisingly they both fit in this without straining the bag (pictures). I also keep a 135mm prime lens for the slr in the bag. I bought this to put my New Lumix S5 in and use it while hiking and also to strap it to the top of the side bags of thr motorcycle. It seems to be well built and is affordable.

My equipment outgrew my old backpack. This one is perfect and I love that it has compartments on the outside. It's also more sturdy than my old backback. I look forward to lugging it through Florida's state parks all summer.

Bag is large and held all my gear with a grab and go bag which works out great 2 cameras 5 lens tri pod mics and misc items all fit. well worth the investment

First off this is THE ONLY backpack you will find that can carry 2 full wedding sets of cameras and then some but not only that it will 100% count as a personal item on 99.9999999% of all airlines. I purchased this bag as my daily carry bag for my laptop and some camera gear. I love all the pockets and configuration. I had traveled with the zipper partway open and I had a loose camera battery inside of one of the partitions. Partitions in this bag are not completely sealed as I can reach my hand from the lens area back through to the laptop area. Make sure you are zipped up before moving around.

can easily make both the top and bottom compartments into one. i can fit 5 lenses a supertelephoto lens and my camera w battery grip in this with some space left for any small items in the main compartment(s) then 2 extra external pockets for whatever like battery chargers extra batteries power bank cords wipes duster flash trigger and filters...has two sides with straps on each where 2 tripods are possible to hold...and this thing fits great..straps for arms and around waist with comfort..heavily padded and thick..i easily have around 35-45lbs in this carrying everything possible and it doesnt dig into your shoulders like other bags/backpacks can. worth the price forsure!!

I received this as a Christmas gift Dec 25 2020.  I was looking forward to this bag as I travel a lot and love photography and have a lot of gear. Drones GoPro's and of course cameras and lenses.  At first inspection it  looked good. So I loaded up my gear and 17" lap top. Yes it will fit a 17 lap top barely.Let me list Pro's and cons :Pro's1 - Lots of small pockets for storing flash drives and manual batteries  ect.2 - Rain cover. I know some of you might not ever need  it but I caught  in the  rain a lot so that was nice.3 - Well padded. (mostly)4 - Outside material looks decent for protection.Cons1 - This is a big one. The zippers are way to cheap for something like this bag. I transferred my gear from my old camera bag to this one. I loaded up the bag with one Nikon three lenses flash batteries and lap top. Not everything I have but the basics. I removed the lap top from the side pocket no problem tight but doable. With the compartment empty I tried to zip it up. The zipper end piece  fell off with NO stress on it. Making  one of the most needed zippers useless. Most of the zippers are way to light for this kind of bag. The pull loops also are not made of strong enough material.2 - This bag will not work as a carry on with  most airlines. The real dimension  are 19" (20" If it is full of gear)x13"x12" Not what they posted on the description  19.7 x 12.0 x 7.5 inches. With the thick heavy straps add even more depth.  I would have a 50/50 chance that they would have me check this bag on most airlines.3 - that brings me to to something some might not think of. This bag has a lot of loose straps zipper pulls bungee cords and plastic buckles all over it.  Great for catching on just about everything and a nightmare if you have to check the bag at the gate.4 - Padding this is more my gripe than a real flaw. This bag is essentially the same bag as the PB-1. They both have the same shape same exterior storage and boast the same 25liter volume capacity. The PB-1 is just slightly larger in exterior dimensions but the volume remains the same. The PB-L is basically the same bag without the bulk of the additional shoulder and waist straps and mesh side pockets.  I chose the PB-L precisely because it was a PB-1 without the bulk.I was able to easily store my Nikon Df with the 50mm attached in the top compartment with my two flash units Peak Design strap 3 camera battery chargers and my MacBook Pro power supply.The inside flap pouch holds my lens filters for my different lenses.All the exterior pouches are handy but don‚Äôt get too excited about packing them up. I‚Äôve been able to store leans cleaning supplies camera USB cables owners manuals pens and my personal pocket reference notebooks for my Df and D850. If you pack them up they won‚Äôt lay right to close the top area of the bag.In the lower compartment is my D850 with my 85mm 1.8D lens attached my 24-85 f2.8 macro zoom my 28-300mm 3.5 VR zoom my classic glass 35-105 2.8 zoom snugly stored in the compartments.The exterior bag holds my Peak Design wrist strap spare clips spare lens caps and covers my Peak design latch carrier system and a small tool kit and adapters for tripods and monopods.Behind the lower side camera access door I have my spare batteries for each camera.My pack weighs in at 19.5 lbs with all my gear. The shoulder straps adjusted high with your heavier gear in the bottom compartment makes for a decently balanced and comfortable pack. My tripod is a cheap one and is very light. Fitted in the side tripod carry pouch it doesn‚Äôt upset the balance of my pack very much at all. Otherwise I would definitely consider using the lower compartment locking straps to secure it horizontally.At nearly 20lbs the pack is decently comfortable for a day hike on or off the trail. It‚Äôs large enough to accommodate the gear most photographers would take for a day event wedding festival or sight seeing. It‚Äôs certainly big enough for all the photography gear I own and durable enough that I don‚Äôt see myself needing to replace it for quite some time.I hope I‚Äôve answered some questions and gotten you a step closer to making a buying decision that is right for you. Cheers.

*'' Aufbau ***Wie auf den Bildern zu sehen ist handelt es sich nicht gerade um einen kleinen Rucksack. Letztere l√§sst sich zus√§tzlich zum H√ºftgurt am Rucksack befestigen. Stichwort H√ºftgurt noch an diesem sind ebenfalls zwei kleine verschlie√übare Taschen untergebracht. Hier ist zum Beispiel Platz f√ºr einen Schl√ºssel oder Reinigungst√ºcher.Beidseitige Halteschlaufen am Rucksack erm√∂glichen √ºbrigens das Mitnehmen von mindestens einem Stativ. In den Netztaschen findet eine 15 Liter PET-Flasche Platz.S√§mtliche Rei√üverschl√ºsse sind mit gro√üen Schlaufen ausgestattet und lassen sich auch noch mit Softshell Handschuhen bewegen f√ºr den Fall dass man mal an k√§lteren Tagen unterwegs ist. Um ein Eindringen von Regenwasser zu verhindern gibt es ein Art √úberstand welcher die Rei√üverschl√ºsse der beiden gro√üen Abteile abdeckt. So ist die Ausr√ºstung definitiv im Trockenen.Die aufgesetzten F√§cher besitzen diesen Schutz nicht. Ebenso muss die Bauchtasche ohne diesen Schutz auskommen.Kommen wir zu den Tr√§gern. Diese lassen sich in der H√∂he der Befestigung am Rucksack anpassen. Ganz gleich ob gro√üe oder kleine Person mehrere Positionierungen sind m√∂glich. Die L√§nge der Gurte l√§sst sich auf individuelle Anspr√ºche verstellen. Sowohl an den Tr√§gern als auch am Bauchgurt. An den Tr√§gern vom Rucksack kann man √ºbrigens eine Kamera einh√§ngen. B√§nder inklusive Karabiner werden mitgeliefert. So st√∂rt bei der Wanderung kein Kameraband im Nacken.Das Obermaterial ist aus wasserabweisendem Nylon f√ºr sehr starke Regeng√ºsse liegt eine Schutzh√ºlle bei. Leider besitzt die Bauchtasche kein separates Regencover. Regnet es also sehr stark sollte man besser die Regenjacke √ºber diese Tasche st√ºlpen.Muss man den Rucksack oder den Bauchgurt absetzten befinden sich am Boden stabile Pads damit Beide sauber stehen bleibt. Diese K√ºr meistert der Tarion ohne Probleme. Erw√§hnenswert: Ein Handgriff oberhalb der Tr√§ger hilft den Rucksack anzuheben und zu schultern. Je nach F√ºllung kommt im PB-01 doch einiges an Gewicht zusammen.Diverse Innenraumteiler liegen dem Rucksack bei. Einige dieser Teiler sind komplett in hellgrau wie auch das Innenfutter des Rucksacks. Manche dieser Teiler haben aber eine helle Seite in der Farbe Orange. Bleiben wir kurz bei der Farbe. Im inneren hellgrau mit Orange an der Au√üenseite haupts√§chlich schwarz mit grauen und orangefarbenen Akzenten.Bleibt noch die Erw√§hnung das auch ein Fach f√ºr ein Laptop vorhanden ist. Best√ºcken kann man √ºber das obere Abteil in dem eine Klappe den Zugang freigibt oder einen Rei√üverschluss an der Seite. Bis zu 17 Zoll Gr√∂√üe kann man unterbringen. Besser kann man es wohl kaum l√∂sen.*** Verarbeitung ***Man k√∂nnte bei dem Preis Bedenken haben ob denn alles sauber verarbeitet ist. Hier kann man eine erste Beruhigung aussprechen. Bei meinem Modell sind alle N√§hte sauber vers√§umt die Rei√üverschl√ºsse laufen gr√∂√ütenteils ohne zu hakeln. Die aufgesetzte Tasche mit Hardcase-Deckel ist eine der Stellen wo es mit dem √ñffnen nicht ganz so sauber l√§uft. Allerdings nur dann wenn man sie komplett √∂ffnen will. Weitere Kritikpunkte bei den Rei√üverschl√ºssen konnte ich nicht finden.Ein h√§ufiger Schwachpunkt an Rucks√§cken sind die Clips der Gurte. Die gr√∂√üte Bef√ºrchtung ist dass diese Clips fummelig sind oder schnell kaputt gehen. Tarion hat das wie folgt gel√∂st: Man hat nicht die hochwertigsten Clips verwendet aber auch keinen totalen Billigschrott. Das Einf√§deln der Clips gelingt sauber schlie√üen fest und wenn sie eingerastet sind dann halten sie auch an den Stellen wo man sie haben will. Rein vom Aussehen des Kunststoffes darf man ein wenig meckern. Dieser d√ºrfte vom optischen Eindruck gerne etwas hochwertiger aussehen.*** Tragekomfort ***Durch die Gr√∂√üe der Tasche packt man mit Sicherheit mehr als nur die kleine Kompaktkamera hinein und schnell kommen 10 Kg Last oder mehr zusammen. Dank dick gepolsterter Trageriemen und Bauchgurt verteilt sich die Last aber gut auf Schulter und H√ºfte.Durch eine luftdurchl√§ssig gepolsterte R√ºckwand hat man immer ein wenig Zirkulation um "unter" dem Rucksack nicht zu √ºberhitzen. Schwitzen wird man an den Stellen wo die Tr√§ger Polster und Gurte anliegen dennoch. Ganz ohne geht es eben nicht.Durch die vielen Gurte sitzt der Rucksack auch stabil in Position wenn man sie denn alle anlegt. Ungewollte Lastwechsel oder das ein Tr√§ger rutscht muss man nicht bef√ºrchten.Die zus√§tzliche Bauchtasche erh√∂ht durch den breiten Gurt zus√§tzlich die Stabilit√§t auch wenn man sich damit vollends als Packesel outet.*** Fassungsverm√∂gen ***Das Wort Packesel ist dann auch die treffende √úberleitung. Denn wichtig bei einem Rucksack ist die Frage was man alles unterbringen kann. Freunde von Spiegelreflex-Kameras d√ºrfen sich auf die Aussage des Herstellers von 2 Bodies (inklusive Batteriegriff) und bis zu sieben Objektiven verlassen. Laptop wie erw√§hnt inklusive. Das Stativ erw√§hne ich an dieser Stelle nicht mehr ebenso wenig den Kleinkram.In der Bauchtasche kann man so einen Body mit Objektiv unterbringen im oberen Fach als "Toploader" ausgebaut ein weiterer Body mit angesetztem Objektiv. Als Nutzer einer Systemkamera im Allgemeinen und MFT im Speziellen k√∂nnte man meinen dass sich Kamera und Objektive in dem Rucksack etwas verlieren. Das mag bei Objektiven wie dem Olympus M.Zuiko 17mm Pancake auch so sein. Bei einem 40-150mm F2.8 Pro sind diese Sorgen unbegr√ºndet.*** Negatives ***Wo Licht ist da ist auch Schatten. Da ich gerne ausf√ºhrlich teste und nichts unter den Tisch fallen lassen will m√∂chte ich auf eine Sache zu sprechen kommen die mir negativ aufgefallen ist. Es geht um den Geruch des Rucksacks nach dem Auspacken. Es roch gelinde gesagt sehr stark nach Chemie um das einmal umgangssprachlich auszudr√ºcken. Drei Tage ausl√ºften an der frischen Luft hat das zum Gl√ºck etwas behoben. Um den Geruch zur G√§nze loszubekommen werden aber ziemlich sicher ein paar weitere Tage n√∂tig sein. Ob es am Transport (Langstrecken Lieferung aus England via UPS) oder andere Gr√ºnde hat kann ich nicht beurteilen. Vielleicht ein Einzelfall vielleicht aber auch nicht. Es erscheint mir daher wichtig dies anzumerken.Ebenfalls fiel mir auf das die Tr√§ger auf der gro√üen Wanderung phasenweise geknarzt haben. Ob sich das mit der Zeit gibt oder einfach dem variablen Tr√§gersystem geschuldet ist kann ich in der K√ºrze der Zeit leider nicht beantworten. Es wird wohl nicht jeden st√∂ren ich selbst blende derartige Ger√§usche mit der Zeit aus.*** Fazit ***Ignoriert man den strengen Geruch zu Anfang so erh√§lt man mit dem Tarion PB-01 eine soliden Rucksack der es versteht viele Anforderungen zu erf√ºllen. Wer lange Wanderungen plant und viel Fotoequipment mit sich f√ºhren will kann oder muss der bringt eine ganze Menge an Ausr√ºstung unter. Ganz perfekt ist der Rucksack freilich nicht. So k√∂nnte man Rei√üverschl√ºsse verwenden welche ohne √úberst√§nde gegen eindringendes Wasser gesch√ºtzt sind oder man verwendet hochwertigere Clips an den Gurten. Das wiederum kann man verschmerzen betrachtet man den Preis. Konkurrenzprodukte von anderen Herstellern welche ein √§hnliches Fassungsverm√∂gen bieten kostet mehr.Ich selbst habe den Rucksack sch√§tzen gelernt und halte ihn f√ºr den f√ºr mich perfekt geeigneten Reisebegleiter auf einer Fotowanderung. Der Rucksack ist Ideal er passt exakt die zus√§tzliche Bauchtasche ist super vielseitig und erg√§nzt das Ganzezu einem tollen kompakt System. Absolut empfehlenswert.
